name: oath

attributes.attribute: witness the truth of a statement
put great stock in verbal truthfulness
made by calling upon either gods or elemental powers
would punish the speaker for lying
would punish the speaker for lying

sources: Cowan, Tom. “The Pledge to the Elements.” In Patricia Monaghan, ed. Irish Spirit: Pagan, Celtic, Christian, Global. Dublin: Wolfhound Press, 2001.
Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text: Ritual acts are an integral part of many societies, including the Celts. In societies like theirs, where there was no written language, great emphasis was placed on verbal truthfulness. Oaths were a means of calling upon divine forces to bear witness to the truth of a statement. Among the Celts, these oaths were often made by invoking either gods or elemental powers like the Sun, Moon, or air, which would then punish the speaker for any falsehood. A common form of the oath among the Celts, who were radically polytheistic, was the phrase, “I swear by the gods my people swear by.”
